title: Joshua Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 23.

questions.question: According to Joshua 23:1, what condition describes Joshua at the time he spoke to Israel?
options: Old and stricken in age
Young and strong
Sick and bedridden
Blind and deaf
questions.correctAnswer: Old and stricken in age
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:1 states that Joshua waxed old and stricken in age after the LORD had given rest unto Israel.

questions.question: Who did Joshua call together according to Joshua 23:2?
options: All Israel, elders, heads, judges, and officers
Only the elders and judges
The priests and Levites
The warriors and prophets
questions.correctAnswer: All Israel, elders, heads, judges, and officers
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:2 shows he called all Israel, including elders, heads, judges, and officers to speak to them.

questions.question: What did Joshua say God had done for Israel according to Joshua 23:3?
options: Fought for you against all nations
Given you wealth and riches
Provided rain and harvest
Built a temple for you
questions.correctAnswer: Fought for you against all nations
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:3 states that the LORD your God is he that hath fought for you and done great things to these nations.

questions.question: What had God divided for the tribes of Israel according to Joshua 23:4?
options: The nations that remain by lot as an inheritance
The land of Egypt
The city of Jerusalem
The holy temple
questions.correctAnswer: The nations that remain by lot as an inheritance
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:4 says God divided by lot the nations remaining to be an inheritance for the tribes of Israel.

questions.question: According to Joshua 23:6, what were the Israelites commanded to be in keeping God's law?
options: Very courageous
Fearful and humble
Silent and obedient
Joyful and singing
questions.correctAnswer: Very courageous
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:6 instructs the Israelites to be very courageous to keep and do all that is written in the law of Moses.

questions.question: What were the Israelites warned not to do with the remaining nations according to Joshua 23:7?
options: Make mention of their gods, swear by them, serve them, or bow down to them
Trade with them freely
Invite them to feasts
Build altars for their gods
questions.correctAnswer: Make mention of their gods, swear by them, serve them, or bow down to them
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:7 commands not to mention the name of their gods, swear by them, serve them, or bow down to them.

questions.question: What does Joshua urge the Israelites to do in Joshua 23:8?
options: Cleave unto the LORD your God as they have done until that day
Go to battle against the remaining nations
Build new altars
Offer sacrifices to other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Cleave unto the LORD your God as they have done until that day
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:8 urges the people to cleave unto the LORD their God as they have done until that day.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 23:9, no man has been able to stand before Israel until that day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:9 states that as for Israel, no man hath been able to stand before them unto that day.

questions.question: What does Joshua say about one man of Israel chasing others in Joshua 23:10?
options: One man of you shall chase a thousand
One man shall chase ten
Ten men will chase one
One man will chase none
questions.correctAnswer: One man of you shall chase a thousand
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:10 promises that one man of Israel shall chase a thousand because the LORD fights for them.

questions.question: According to Joshua 23:11, what must the Israelites take good heed to do?
options: Love the LORD your God
Build strong walls
Harvest crops diligently
Remember their ancestors
questions.correctAnswer: Love the LORD your God
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:11 instructs the Israelites to take good heed to love the LORD their God.

questions.question: What consequence does Joshua warn about in Joshua 23:13 if the Israelites go back to the remaining nations?
options: The LORD will no more drive out the nations and they will be snares and thorns to Israel
They will become wealthy
They will gain more land
They will live peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will no more drive out the nations and they will be snares and thorns to Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:13 warns that if Israel cleaves to the remaining nations, the LORD will not drive them out and they will become snares and thorns.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua said in Joshua 23:14 that not one thing has failed of all the good things the LORD promised Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:14 confirms that all the good things the LORD promised Israel have come to pass without failure.

questions.question: What will happen to Israel if they transgress the covenant and serve other gods according to Joshua 23:16?
options: The anger of the LORD will be kindled and they shall perish quickly
They will be blessed and prosper
They will be forgiven immediately
They will receive new lands
questions.correctAnswer: The anger of the LORD will be kindled and they shall perish quickly
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:16 states that if Israel serves other gods, the LORD's anger will be kindled and they shall perish quickly from the land.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 23:15 states that just as good things have come upon Israel, so shall evil things come until destruction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:15 declares that as all good things have come upon Israel, so will all evil things come until destruction if they disobey.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Joshua 23:5: 'And the LORD your God, he shall ______ them from before you, and drive them from out of your sight; and ye shall possess their land.'
options: expel
bless
protect
curse
questions.correctAnswer: expel
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:5 says that the LORD your God shall expel them from before you and drive them away.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Joshua 23 teach us about trusting in God's faithfulness during difficult times?
options: God has fought for His people and fulfilled all His promises
We must rely on our own strength to overcome enemies
God sometimes fails to protect His people
Promises are conditional and often unfulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: God has fought for His people and fulfilled all His promises
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:3 and Joshua 23:14 emphasize that the LORD has fought for Israel and that not one promise has failed, demonstrating God's faithfulness and encouraging trust in Him during challenges.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commands. Based on Joshua 23, what biblical truth would you share about obedience?
options: Obedience leads to courage and blessings from God
Obedience is optional and has no real consequences
Only partial obedience is necessary for God's favor
Obedience is only about external actions, not the heart
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to courage and blessings from God
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:6 encourages courage to keep all written in the law of Moses, and Joshua 23:14-15 remind that blessings come when obedience is maintained, while disobedience brings consequences.

questions.question: What warning does Joshua 23 give about associating with nations that remain among Israel?
options: They can become snares, traps, and cause Israel's downfall
They will help Israel remain strong
They are harmless and should be embraced
They will convert to Israel's God without issue
questions.correctAnswer: They can become snares, traps, and cause Israel's downfall
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:12-13 warns that marrying or associating with remaining nations will cause them to be snares and thorns leading to Israel's ruin if they turn away from God.

questions.question: According to Joshua 23, how should believers respond to temptation to serve other gods?
options: Cleave to the LORD and avoid serving other gods
Serve other gods if it benefits their lives
Ignore God's commands about other gods
Worship other gods privately without concern
questions.correctAnswer: Cleave to the LORD and avoid serving other gods
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:7-8 and 23:16 instruct believers to not serve or bow to other gods but to remain faithful to the LORD to avoid His anger and destruction.

questions.question: How does Joshua 23 encourage believers to maintain their spiritual discipline and devotion?
options: By loving the LORD and obeying His covenant diligently
By seeking advice from surrounding nations
By following cultural customs over God's laws
By relying on past victories rather than daily faith
questions.correctAnswer: By loving the LORD and obeying His covenant diligently
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:11 emphasizes the importance of loving the LORD, and 23:6 and 23:16 stress obedience to His covenant as vital for spiritual discipline and relationship with God.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 23 says that no man has been able to stand against Israel because the LORD fights for them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:9-10 affirm that the LORD has driven out great nations before Israel and that He fights for them, enabling one man to chase a thousand.

questions.question: What is the practical lesson about humility and contentment in Joshua 23 when Joshua says he is old and going the way of all the earth?
options: Recognize that life is transient and trust God’s faithfulness
Seek to extend life by human effort
Ignore aging and focus only on material success
Fear death and avoid talking about it
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that life is transient and trust God’s faithfulness
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:1 and 23:14 highlight Joshua’s awareness of mortality while affirming God’s unchanging promises, teaching believers to live humbly and trust God throughout life.

questions.question: How should believers approach marriage and family life according to Joshua 23?
options: Avoid intermarriage with those who do not follow God’s covenant
Marry whomever they choose without regard to faith
Marry only for social or political advantages
Ignore spiritual compatibility in marriage
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid intermarriage with those who do not follow God’s covenant
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:12 warns against marrying from the remaining nations as it leads to turning away from God, highlighting the importance of faithfulness in family relationships.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their faith by adopting worldly practices. Based on Joshua 23, what counsel would you give?
options: Remain courageous and strictly follow God’s law without deviation
Compromise slightly to fit in with others
Adopt some worldly practices to gain favor
Ignore God’s commands if it benefits your situation
questions.correctAnswer: Remain courageous and strictly follow God’s law without deviation
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:6 urges courage to keep all written in the law without turning to the right or left, encouraging steadfastness in obedience and avoiding compromise.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 23 declares that if Israel transgresses the covenant and serves other gods, God’s anger will be kindled and they will perish quickly from the land.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:16 clearly states that disobedience and idolatry will provoke God’s anger and lead to Israel’s destruction from the land He gave them.

questions.question: What does Joshua 23 teach about the role of God’s Word in daily decision-making and integrity?
options: God’s law is the standard and must be followed exactly
One can choose which parts of God’s law to obey
God’s Word is outdated and flexible
Integrity is independent of God's commandments
questions.correctAnswer: God’s law is the standard and must be followed exactly
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:6 and 23:14 emphasize obedience to all that is written in the law of Moses without deviation, showing the importance of God’s Word as a foundation for integrity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joshua told Israel to be very ______ to keep and do all that is written in the book of the law of Moses.
options: courageous
careless
fearful
doubtful
questions.correctAnswer: courageous
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:6 instructs the Israelites to be very courageous in keeping and doing all that is written in the law, highlighting bold obedience.

questions.question: According to Joshua 23, what is the result of loving the LORD your God?
options: Possessing the land and receiving God's blessings
Being able to ignore God’s commands
Living without any trials or difficulties
Having no need to fight against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Possessing the land and receiving God's blessings
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:5 and 23:11 show that loving the LORD leads to possessing the land as promised and enjoying His blessings, while disobedience leads to loss.

questions.question: What does Joshua 23 teach about perseverance through trials and spiritual warfare?
options: God fights for His people, empowering them to overcome many enemies
Believers must fight alone without God’s help
Trials are signs of God’s abandonment
Victory depends on human strength only
questions.correctAnswer: God fights for His people, empowering them to overcome many enemies
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:9-10 teaches that the LORD drives out enemies and fights for Israel, enabling one man to chase a thousand, encouraging perseverance with God's help.

questions.question: How does Joshua 23 instruct believers about the consequences of turning away from God?
options: They will face destruction and be removed from the good land
They will continue to prosper without consequence
God will ignore their rebellion
They will be blessed despite disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: They will face destruction and be removed from the good land
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:15-16 warn that transgressing the covenant and serving other gods will bring evil upon them and result in their destruction from the land God gave them.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 23.

questions.question: What reason does Joshua give for calling all Israel and their leaders together in Joshua 23?
options: Because he was old and stricken in age
To divide the land by lot
To celebrate a festival
To appoint new judges
questions.correctAnswer: Because he was old and stricken in age
questions.explanation: Joshua calls all Israel because he is old and stricken in age, as stated in Joshua 23:2.

questions.question: In Joshua 23, what does Joshua remind Israel about the LORD’s role in their conquest?
options: The LORD fought for them
They conquered by their own strength
They made alliances with other nations
They built a temple to honor the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD fought for them
questions.explanation: Joshua reminds Israel that the LORD their God is the one who fought for them against their enemies (Joshua 23:3).

questions.question: What geographical boundaries does Joshua mention for the inheritance given to the tribes of Israel?
options: From Jordan to the great sea westward
From the Nile to the Euphrates
From Mount Sinai to the Dead Sea
From the Red Sea to the Mediterranean
questions.correctAnswer: From Jordan to the great sea westward
questions.explanation: Joshua describes the land divided by lot from the Jordan River to the great sea westward (Joshua 23:4).

questions.question: What does Joshua urge the Israelites to be in order to keep the law of Moses?
options: Very courageous
Quiet and humble
Fearful and cautious
Patient and forgiving
questions.correctAnswer: Very courageous
questions.explanation: Joshua commands them to be very courageous to keep and do all that is written in the book of the law of Moses (Joshua 23:6).

questions.question: According to Joshua 23, what must the Israelites avoid in relation to the remaining nations among them?
options: Mentioning the name of their gods and serving them
Trading with them
Visiting their cities
Learning their languages
questions.correctAnswer: Mentioning the name of their gods and serving them
questions.explanation: Joshua instructs them not to mention the name of their gods, swear by them, serve them, or bow down to them (Joshua 23:7).

questions.question: What is the Hebrew term often translated as 'inheritance' in this chapter, and what is its significance in the context of Joshua 23:4?
options: Nachalah – denoting the land given by God as a lasting possession
Shekel – referring to a unit of currency
Torah – meaning the law given to Israel
Kohen – indicating priestly duties
questions.correctAnswer: Nachalah – denoting the land given by God as a lasting possession
questions.explanation: The word 'inheritance' (nachalah) refers to the land allotted by God as a permanent possession for Israel’s tribes, underscoring divine promise and covenant (Joshua 23:4).

questions.question: What consequence does Joshua warn will happen if Israel turns back and cleaves to the remnant nations by intermarriage?
options: The LORD will no longer drive out these nations and they will become snares and traps
They will receive greater blessings
They will gain new territories
They will become priests and Levites
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will no longer drive out these nations and they will become snares and traps
questions.explanation: Joshua warns that if they intermarry and cleave to the remaining nations, the LORD will stop driving them out and they will become snares, traps, scourges, and thorns (Joshua 23:12-13).

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Joshua 23:10 where it says, 'One man of you shall chase a thousand'?
options: Hyperbole emphasizing God's empowerment
Chiasm illustrating cause and effect
Metaphor for farming
Paradox about weakness
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole emphasizing God's empowerment
questions.explanation: The phrase uses hyperbole to stress the extraordinary victory made possible by God’s fighting on Israel’s behalf (Joshua 23:10).

questions.question: Joshua 23:14 contains a solemn declaration about the fulfillment of God's promises. How does this reflect a major theme throughout the Deuteronomistic history?
options: God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises
The inevitability of exile
The futility of human effort
The importance of temple worship
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises
questions.explanation: Joshua affirms that none of the good promises has failed, highlighting God’s unwavering faithfulness, a central theme in Deuteronomistic history (Joshua 23:14).

questions.question: What is the significance of Joshua’s statement in verse 14 regarding 'going the way of all the earth'?
options: It signifies his approaching death and transition of leadership
It predicts the conquest of Canaan
It announces a new covenant
It calls for a festival
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies his approaching death and transition of leadership
questions.explanation: Joshua acknowledges his mortality and impending death, preparing Israel for leadership transition (Joshua 23:14).

questions.question: According to Joshua 23, what will happen if Israel transgresses the covenant and serves other gods?
options: The LORD’s anger will be kindled and they will perish quickly from the land
They will be forgiven without consequence
They will gain more land
They will be made priests
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD’s anger will be kindled and they will perish quickly from the land
questions.explanation: Joshua warns that violation of the covenant by idol worship will provoke God's anger and lead to swift destruction (Joshua 23:16).

questions.question: True or False: Joshua commands the people to serve and bow down to the gods of the nations remaining among them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua explicitly forbids serving or bowing down to the gods of the remaining nations (Joshua 23:7).

questions.question: In Joshua 23, what does the phrase 'cleave unto the LORD your God' typify in Israel’s covenant relationship?
options: Loyalty and exclusive devotion
Physical separation from others
Financial offerings
Temple building
questions.correctAnswer: Loyalty and exclusive devotion
questions.explanation: To 'cleave unto' the LORD signifies steadfast loyalty and exclusive commitment to God, a core covenant expectation (Joshua 23:8).

questions.question: What historical context underlies the warning against intermarriage with the remaining nations in Joshua 23:12-13?
options: To prevent idolatry and preserve Israel’s covenant purity
To form political alliances
To expand economic trade
To learn foreign languages
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent idolatry and preserve Israel’s covenant purity
questions.explanation: Intermarriage was seen as a threat to covenant faithfulness because it often led to idolatry and cultural assimilation (Joshua 23:12-13).

questions.question: How does Joshua 23:9-10 illustrate a typology that foreshadows New Testament themes of spiritual warfare?
options: By showing that God fights on behalf of His people
By commanding temple sacrifices
By focusing on agricultural laws
By predicting the building of the church
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that God fights on behalf of His people
questions.explanation: The emphasis on divine warfare in Joshua anticipates New Testament teachings on spiritual battles where God empowers believers (Joshua 23:9-10).

questions.question: What is the thematic significance of the phrase 'not one thing hath failed' in Joshua 23:14 for the original audience?
options: It reassures Israel of God’s trustworthy covenant amidst challenges
It predicts immediate exile
It highlights Joshua’s leadership alone
It calls for rebuilding the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It reassures Israel of God’s trustworthy covenant amidst challenges
questions.explanation: This phrase reassures Israel that God is faithful and all promises have been fulfilled, encouraging trust despite future difficulties (Joshua 23:14).

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Joshua 23, what is the primary reason Joshua exhorts Israel to be courageous and obey the Law of Moses strictly?
options: Because the LORD your God has fought for you and given you victory
Because the nations around them are weak and will not resist
Because Joshua will personally lead them into battle
Because the Law of Moses is easy to follow
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD your God has fought for you and given you victory
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:3-6 states that the LORD fought for Israel, giving them rest from enemies, and Joshua urges courage to keep the Law. This emphasizes God's providential victory and covenantal call to obedience, consistent with Deuteronomy 31:6, 2 Chronicles 20:17, Romans 8:31, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: In Joshua 23, what consequence does Joshua warn will happen if Israel intermingles and marries with the remaining nations?
options: The LORD will no longer drive out these nations and they will become snares
They will gain new allies for protection
They will be blessed with more land
They will be given more judges to rule over them
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will no longer drive out these nations and they will become snares
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:12-13 warns that intermarriage with remaining nations will stop God's driving out of enemies, leading to snares and thorns, causing Israel's spiritual and national downfall. This aligns with warnings in Deuteronomy 7:3-4, Nehemiah 13:23-27, 1 Corinthians 15:33, and James 4:4.

questions.question: What does Joshua say about the fulfillment of God's promises to Israel in this chapter?
options: Not one of all the good promises has failed
Many promises remain unfulfilled
God has forgotten His covenant
Only some promises were fulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: Not one of all the good promises has failed
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:14 affirms that every good thing promised by God to Israel has come to pass without failure, highlighting God's faithfulness in covenant fulfillment. This doctrine of God's unchanging faithfulness is echoed in Numbers 23:19, 2 Timothy 2:13, Hebrews 10:23, and Psalm 89:34.

questions.question: How does Joshua describe the LORD’s role in Israel’s victories over great and strong nations?
options: The LORD is the one who fights for Israel
Israel's military skill alone won the battles
The nations surrendered without fighting
Victory was due to alliances with other tribes
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is the one who fights for Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:9-10 declares that God drove out great nations and that it is the LORD who fights for Israel, affirming divine sovereignty in salvation and victory. This aligns with Exodus 15:3, Judges 7:2, Psalm 44:3, and Romans 8:37.

questions.question: What does Joshua identify as the ultimate consequence if Israel transgresses the covenant and serves other gods?
options: They shall perish quickly from the good land
They will be forgiven without consequence
They will be given a second chance immediately
They will be exiled but spared from death
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish quickly from the good land
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:16 states that disobedience and idolatry will kindle the LORD’s anger, causing Israel to perish quickly from the land given by God. This reflects covenantal curses found in Deuteronomy 28:15, 2 Chronicles 7:19-22, Jeremiah 11:3-5, and Hebrews 10:26-31.

questions.question: Which exhortation does Joshua give to Israel to maintain their relationship with God in chapter 23?
options: Cleave unto the LORD your God as you have done until this day
Build altars to the gods of the remaining nations
Neglect the Law of Moses since Joshua is old
Form political alliances with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Cleave unto the LORD your God as you have done until this day
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:8 commands Israel to cling to the LORD as they have so far, emphasizing steadfast faithfulness. This call for covenant loyalty is consistent with Deuteronomy 10:20, Psalm 73:28, John 15:4-5, and James 4:8.

questions.question: What does Joshua say about the distribution of the remaining nations' lands to Israel's tribes?
options: He has divided them by lot as an inheritance
He will distribute them after his death
They must conquer them all by themselves
He will leave the lands unassigned
questions.correctAnswer: He has divided them by lot as an inheritance
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:4 explains that Joshua has allotted the remaining nations’ lands by lot to Israel’s tribes, indicating God's sovereign provision and order in land possession. This practice is noted in Numbers 26:55, Deuteronomy 18:6, Acts 1:26, and Psalm 16:6.

questions.question: What is the nature of the 'thorns in your eyes' and 'scourges in your sides' mentioned in Joshua 23?
options: They symbolize the ongoing troubles from remaining nations if Israel disobeys
They represent physical punishment from God
They are blessings for obedience
They signify peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize the ongoing troubles from remaining nations if Israel disobeys
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:13 uses these metaphors to describe the persistent troubles and dangers from disobedience and associating with the remaining nations, consistent with similar imagery in Numbers 33:55, Judges 2:3, Psalm 119:165, and Revelation 2:10.

questions.question: How does Joshua describe his own condition at the beginning of chapter 23?
options: Old and stricken in age
Young and vigorous
Sick but hopeful
Unknown condition
questions.correctAnswer: Old and stricken in age
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:1-2 states that Joshua was old and advanced in years, indicating he was preparing Israel for leadership transition. This reflects biblical themes of faithful elders nearing the end of their ministry, seen also in Moses (Deuteronomy 34:7), David (1 Kings 1:1), and Paul (2 Timothy 4:6-7).

questions.question: What does Joshua say about the LORD’s promises concerning evil if Israel disobeys?
options: The LORD will bring all evil things upon you until destroyed
The LORD will overlook your sins
You will face no consequences for your actions
The LORD will remove evil from your land
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will bring all evil things upon you until destroyed
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:15 warns that the LORD will bring evil upon Israel until destroyed if they break the covenant, affirming divine justice consistent with Deuteronomy 28:45-46, Ezekiel 18:20, Romans 6:23, and Hebrews 12:6.

questions.question: What is the basis for Joshua’s confidence that Israel has possessed the land as promised by God?
options: Because the LORD your God has driven out nations and fought for you
Because Israel's army is stronger now
Because the other nations made peace with Israel
Because Joshua made alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD your God has driven out nations and fought for you
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:5-6 and verse 9 affirm that God fought for Israel and drove out nations, establishing possession of the land, demonstrating God's covenant faithfulness, consistent with Exodus 23:31, Deuteronomy 11:24, Psalm 44:3, and Romans 4:20-21.

questions.question: What does Joshua instruct Israel not to do concerning the gods of the nations that remain among them?
options: Do not mention their names, swear by them, serve them, or bow down to them
Invite their priests to teach Israel
Make alliances with their gods
Ignore their existence
questions.correctAnswer: Do not mention their names, swear by them, serve them, or bow down to them
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:7 forbids Israel from invoking or serving the gods of remaining nations, reaffirming exclusive worship of Yahweh, which aligns with Exodus 20:3-5, Deuteronomy 6:14-15, 1 Corinthians 10:20, and Revelation 14:7.

questions.question: What does Joshua say about the ability of any man to stand against Israel so far?
options: No man has been able to stand before you to this day
Several men have defeated Israel
Israel has often been defeated in battle
The record is uncertain
questions.correctAnswer: No man has been able to stand before you to this day
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:9 states that no man has been able to stand against Israel, emphasizing divine protection and victory, consistent with passages like Judges 6:12, Psalm 18:39, Isaiah 54:17, and Romans 8:37.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the phrase 'One man of you shall chase a thousand' in the context of Joshua 23?
options: God’s power enables Israel to overcome enemies disproportionately
Israel will multiply their army
Each soldier must fight a thousand enemies
The number is symbolic of failure
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power enables Israel to overcome enemies disproportionately
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:10 illustrates that victory is by God’s enabling power, not human strength, reflecting divine sovereignty in battles, as seen in 2 Chronicles 32:7, Psalm 44:3, 1 Samuel 17:47, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: What final instruction does Joshua give regarding love for the LORD in chapter 23?
options: Take good heed and love the LORD your God
Forget the LORD and seek peace with nations
Love only your family and ignore God
Serve other gods to gain favor
questions.correctAnswer: Take good heed and love the LORD your God
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:11 exhorts Israel to carefully love the LORD, underscoring the covenantal relationship based on love, which is central to biblical ethics, supported by Deuteronomy 6:5, Matthew 22:37, John 14:15, and 1 John 4:7.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by Joshua’s statement that he is ‘going the way of all the earth’?
options: The universality of death and human mortality
His intention to retire and live in peace
His journey to a foreign land
His refusal to lead further battles
questions.correctAnswer: The universality of death and human mortality
questions.explanation: Joshua 23:14 acknowledges his impending death, highlighting the biblical truth of human mortality, consistent with Ecclesiastes 3:20, Hebrews 9:27, Psalm 90:3-4, and James 4:14.
